input_text: simplify to A2: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. input_text: simplify to B1: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
target_text: If we want to know where our ability for complex language came from, we need to look at how the human brain is different from the brains of other animals. It is not only about brain size, but also about what our brains can do, when these abilities appreared and why. There are a few physical clues about this, because objects from early humans cannot show us what kind of speech thry used. But one thing we can study is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. Around 100,000 years ago, humans developed the ability to make complex sounds. Before that, scientists could only guess if early humans used simpler sounds to communicate.

input_text: simplify to B1: Another suggested defence against a PHA on course to hit Earth is to blow it up using a nuclear weapon. It may sound like a plot from a film, and it was the subject of the 1998 film Armageddon, but the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a genuine NASA proposal. The eight-ton rockets would be fired at an approaching asteroid with the hope of bumping it off course. If the asteroid was too close to Earth for this plan to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.
target_text: Another way to stop an asteroid from hitting Earth is to destroy it with a nuclear weapon. This may sound like a film story, and it was actually in the 1998 film Armageddon. However, the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a real project from NASA. The plan was to send eight-ton heavy rockets towards an asteroid to push it away from its path. If the asteroid is already too close to Earth, the rockets could carry nuclear bombs to break it apart.

input_text: simplify to A2: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Furthermore, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they may mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and see science as an unappealing career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
target_text: Society tells us that girls should choose arts and humanities, and boys should choose maths and physics. Another problem is that children do not often see women working in science. In cartoons and stories, the scientist, inventor, or astronaut is usually a man. People also think scientists are strange, not good at talking to others, or always working alone. These ideas are not true, but they can make girls feel that science is not for them. If girls saw more women in science, they would feel more confident and feel that they belong in those subjects.

input_text: simplify to A2: Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck spoke of the plasticity of the brain and our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to focus our praise on the end result and seemingly innate talents, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research suggests that by focusing on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation and problem-solving strategies – we can encourage the development of new skills and the continued honing of talents.
target_text: Psychologist Carol Dweck talks about the 'growth mindset'. This means the brain can change, and we can learn skills even if we are not good at them at the start. Often, people give praise only for the final result or for natural talent. For example: "You notice small details well" or "You are good at organising events." But research shows it is better to praise the way people work. Saying something like "Good effort" or "Good for trying new ideas" helps people learn new skills and improve their talents.

input_text: simplify to B1: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? target_text: More questions appear if we look at the historical effects of our biology on our brains and language development. In the past, did changes in our biology give us language ability? Research has found a change that took place between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, and it seems this change is connected with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and faces. Monkeys have a similar biology to us, but they did not experience this change. Have changes like this affected our language development, and if so, how much? It's too early for us to know yet, but one day, after more research, we might find the answers.

input_text: simplify to A2: Spider venom is present in most species and serves the purpose of stunning or killing their prey rather than attacking humans. In fact, only 25 of the known spider species produce venom which can actually harm humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly. Australia's notorious Sydney funnel-web spider has not produced any fatalities since anti-venom was developed in 1981. However, take care not to rub hairy spiders like tarantulas up the wrong way. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.
target_text: Most spiders have venom, but it is for catching food, not for hurting people. Only about 25 kinds of spiders can harm humans. A spider bite can be painful, but it rarely kills. In Australia, the Sydney funnel-web spider has not killed anyone since doctors made an anti-venom in 1981. But be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. If they feel danger, they throw out tiny hairs. These hairs can get into your skin or eyes and make them very sore.

input_text: simplify to B1: If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.
target_text: After the age of ten, most people have between four and six dreams each night. That adds up to about 2,000 dreams a year. By the time someone turns 80, they may have had around 140,000 dreams. Even though we forget most dreams–about 95 to 99 percent–we still remember thousands over a lifetime. So, it's not hard to believe that sometimes a dream is followed by a real-life event that feels similar, especially when it's about something that happens often in everyday life.

input_text: simplify to B1: Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck spoke of the plasticity of the brain and our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to focus our praise on the end result and seemingly innate talents, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research suggests that by focusing on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation and problem-solving strategies – we can encourage the development of new skills and the continued honing of talents.

input_text: simplify to B1: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. Positive feedback should not just be used to cover the negatives. It should be given clearly to support the good work.

input_text: simplify to B1: In older horror films, when protagonists were in desperation, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less believable now. What's the solution to maintain suspense? No phone coverage! input_text: simplify to B1: One of the most important modern functions of zoos is supporting international breeding programmes, particularly for endangered species. A good zoo will enable these species to live and breed in a secure environment. In addition, as numbers of some wild species drop, there is an increased danger of populations becoming too genetically similar. Breeding programmes provide a safeguard: zoo-bred animals can be released into the wild to increase genetic diversity.
target_text: One of the most important roles of zoos is supporting international breeding programmes, especially for animals that are endangered. In the wild, some rare animals find it hard to find partners and have babies. They are also in danger from hunters, the loss of their homes, and other animals that hunt them. A good zoo gives these species a safe place to live and reproduce. Another problem is that when the number of animals in the wild becomes very small, they can become too genetically similar. Breeding programmes help with this, because animals born in zoos can later be relaesed into the wild to make the population stronger and more diverse.
